That's what I call a challenge!

What I would do:

- be aware that you cannot find every bug with unit testing.  Having 
100% coverage of your code unit tested doesn't mean that your product 
has no bug.  Try other testing approach too.
- how confident are you that one module is working fine or not?  Start 
by testing the modules you think are the more likely to have bugs.  If 
some kind of tests already exist for some buggy module, try to recompile 
and execute them.  If you don't have tests, it's the right time to write 
some.  (I don't know how many tests you have already written, it's maybe 
too time consuming to fix them all right now, or maybe not).
- force the tests to be compiled and executed during the normal build
- it can frustrating for developers to face a huge buggy code so try to 
find metrics showing that you are making progress (# open bugs, class 
testes, % coverage).

-Vladimir

--
